citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The refrigerator in the kennel in which vaccines are kept is not cold. The licensee states they have a problem with the
reliability of the mechanism that keeps the refrigerator cold. Vaccines typically are labeled to be stored at 36 to 46
degrees F. Vaccines that are not stored appropriately may no longer be effective. An ineffective vaccine cannot properly
protect dogs from the diseases they are meant to prevent. The licensee must ensure that the availability of appropriate
equipment is provided to adequately store vaccines. Correct by April 1, 2023.

The licensee has not been doing monthly heartworm preventative for the dogs. The Program of Veterinary Care (PVC)
instructs the licensee to use a product topically each month for adult dogs. The licensee states sometimes they do it but
not to every dog and not every month. Heartworm disease is a blood parasite spread through mosquitos that can cause
coughing, heart disease, pain and/or distress to dogs. Sampling and treatment of parasites (including heartworm) in
accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian must be followed by the licensee. Correct by ensuring
that heartworm prevention is used as stated in the PVC. Correct by: April 1, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The refrigerator in the kennel in which vaccines are kept is not cold. The licensee states they have a problem with the 
reliability of the mechanism that keeps the refrigerator cold. Vaccines typically are labeled to be stored at 36 to 46 
degrees F. Vaccines that are not stored appropriately may no longer be effective. An ineffective vaccine cannot properly 
protect dogs from the diseases they are meant to prevent. The licensee must ensure that the availability of appropriate 
equipment is provided to adequately store vaccines. Correct by April 1, 2023. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee has not been doing monthly heartworm preventative for the dogs. The Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) 
instructs the licensee to use a product topically each month for adult dogs. The licensee states sometimes they do it but 
not to every dog and not every month. Heartworm disease is a blood parasite spread through mosquitos that can cause 
coughing, heart disease, pain and/or distress to dogs. Sampling and treatment of parasites (including heartworm) in 
accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian must be followed by the licensee. Correct by ensuring 
that heartworm prevention is used as stated in the PVC. Correct by: April 1, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
